abstract.p: Loree E Peery letter comments on Jan 8 debate on whether specially trained nurses can safely administer anesthesia without physician supervision

block.p: Re the Facing Off column ''On the Front Line in the O.R.; Can Specially Trained Nurses Safely Administer Anesthesia Without Physician Supervision?'' (Jan. 8):
I am a registered nurse with 20 years of operating room experience. I have worked with both nurse anesthetists and physician anesthesiologists.
Re the Facing Off column ''On the Front Line in the O.R.; Can Specially Trained Nurses Safely Administer Anesthesia Without Physician Supervision?'' (Jan. 8):
I am a registered nurse with 20 years of operating room experience. I have worked with both nurse anesthetists and physician anesthesiologists.

I have worked in rural hospitals and large urban hospitals. I have observed thousands of anesthetics' being administered by both practitioners. When I became a patient and needed surgery, I requested a nurse anesthetist.
The care given by nurse anesthetists is equal to that of a physician, with one exception: it is personal and attentive.

The nursing school background is a plus; it adds a human element. I have worked with anesthesiologists in training, and I actually heard one say that he went into anesthesia so that he wouldn't have to talk with patients.
He left the anesthetized patient unattended to walk over to tell me this.
Nurses are trained to be patient advocates.
LOREE E. PEERY Chula Vista, Calif.
